facts.text: Petition No. 82 of 1959 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 82 of 1959. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 22, 1961 by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 22. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Seven petitioners challenge Rajasthan Passengers and Goods Taxation Act, 1959, Rules 1959, and notification under Rule 8 as unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners, who are seven in number, challenge as unconstitutional and ultra vires certain provisions of the Rajasthan Passengers and Goods Taxation Act, 1959, the Rajasthan Passengers and Goods Taxation Rules, 1959, and a notification issued under R. 8.

facts.text: First petitioner is a registered firm, petitioners 2 to 6 are partners, petitioner 7 is General Manager holding public carrier permit for whole Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: The first petitioner is a registered firm, petitioners Nos. 2 to 6 are the partners of that firm, and petitioner No. 7 is the General Manager of the firm. Petitioner No. 7 holds a public carrier permit for the whole of Rajasthan in his individual name.

facts.text: Petitioners hold 59 stage carriage permits from Regional Transport Authority, Jodhpur for diverse routes with different road surfaces.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners also hold 59 stage carriage permits from the Regional Transport Authority, Jodhpur, for diverse routes over roads which have different kinds of surfaces, some being sandy or katcha and others, metalled., tarred, etc.

facts.text: Rajasthan Passengers and Goods Taxation Act, 1959 passed for levying tax on passengers and goods carried by road in motor vehicles.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was passed in 1959 for levying a tax on passengers and goods carried by road in motor vehicles. The power to enact the Act purports to be derived from Entry No. 56 of the State List in Sch. VII to the Constitution,

facts.text: Act received President's assent on April 27, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: which reads Taxes on goods and passengers carried by road or on inland waterways. The Act received the assent of the President on April 27, 19.59, and was published in the Rajasthan Gazette on April 30, 1959.

facts.text: Act published in Rajasthan Gazette on April 30, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The Act received the assent of the President on April 27, 19.59, and was published in the Rajasthan Gazette on April 30, 1959. The same day, the Rules framed in exercise of the powers conferred by s. 21 of the Act were also published,

facts.text: Rules framed under section 21 published on April 30, 1959 and subsequently amended.

anchor.surface_text: The same day, the Rules framed in exercise of the powers conferred by s. 21 of the Act were also published, and the notification was also issued. The Rules were subsequently amended, and we are concerned with the Rules, as amended.

facts.text: Act came into force on May 1, 1959 in whole State of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: The Act, which consists of 21, sections, came into force in the whole of the State of Rajasthan on May 1, 1959.

facts.text: Notification issued under Rule 8 on April 30, 1959 from Jaipur prescribing lump sum rates for public carriers.

anchor.surface_text: The notification which was issued under R. 8 prescribing lump sum rates, is as follows Jaipur, April 30, 1959 No. F. 15 5  E T/59. III-.-In pursuance of rule 8 of the Rajasthan Passengers and Goods Taxation Rules, 1959,

facts.text: Section 3 levies tax on fares and freights for passengers carried and goods transported by motor vehicles at rates not exceeding 1/8 or 1/12 of value depending on road type.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 is the charging section, and s. 4 deals with the method of collection of the tax. ... Levy of tax.- 1  There shall be levied, charged and paid to the State Government, a tax on all fares and freights in respect of all passengers carried and goods transported by motor vehicles at such rate not exceeding one-eighth of the value of the fare or freight,

facts.text: Petitioners contend tax is on fares and freights, not passengers and goods, ultra vires Entry 56.

anchor.surface_text: The main objection to the Act is that the tax has not been laid upon passengers and goods as authorised by Entry No. 56 but upon fares and freights, which are different entities,

facts.text: Court holds tax is on passengers and goods, measured by fares and freights.

anchor.surface_text: We do not agree that the Act, in its pith, and substance, lays the tax upon income and not upon passengers and goods. Section 3, in terms, speaks of the charge of the tax in respect of all passengers carried and goods transported by motor vehicles,

facts.text: Petitioners challenge Act as repugnant to Articles 301, 304, 19, 14.

anchor.surface_text: The Act and the Rules are further challenged on the grounds that they are repugnant to Arts. 301 and 304 as being a restriction upon inter-State trade, commerce and intercourse, to Art. 19 as involving an unreasonable restriction upon the business of the petitioners, and also to Art. 14 as discriminating between this mode of transport and the Railways.

facts.text: Court holds no impact on inter-State trade, commerce or intercourse.

anchor.surface_text: We are also of opinion that no inter-State trade, commerce or intercourse is affected. The tax is for purposes of State, and falls upon passengers and goods carried by motor vehicles within the State.

facts.text: Rules 8 and 8-A make lump sum payment compulsory, contrary to optional under Section 4.

anchor.surface_text: Rules 8 and 8-A and the notification are challenged as, it is submitted, they go beyond the Act by making the lump sum payment compulsory, even though under the Act it is optional,

facts.text: Court holds lump sum payment optional, Rules prescribe amounts harmoniously with Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Act and the Rules must be read harmoniously, and reading them so, it is plain that the apparent mandatory language of the Rules and the notification still retains the permissive character of the section,

facts.text: Petitioners contend discrimination between road transport and railways under Art 14.

anchor.surface_text: and also to Art. 14 as discriminating between this mode of transport and the Railways.

facts.text: Court holds no discrimination as railways are Union subject.

anchor.surface_text: The comparison with Railways is not admissible, because tax on railway fares and freights is a Union subject, and is not available to the State Legislature. There is thus a clear classification made by the Constitution itself.

facts.text: Higher tax rates for better roads (cemented, tarred etc.) discriminate between operators.

anchor.surface_text: The rates and lump sum payment are challenged because they involve discrimination between routes involving roads of different surfaces.

facts.text: Court holds graded tax justified by cost of construction and maintenance of roads.

anchor.surface_text: They will be heavy in case of roads requiring greater expenditure to construct and to maintain, than in case of roads not requiring such expenditure. All operators using the better kind of roads have to pay the heavier tax,

facts.text: Proviso to s.3(3) has extra-territorial operation.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it is said that by making tax payable even though the route between two intra-State point passes outside the State, the Act has an extra-territorial operation which is ultra vires the legislature.

facts.text: No affidavit filed on number of such routes or extent.

anchor.surface_text: No affidavit was sworn to show how many such routes were involved and what their extent was, and in view of lack of adequate averments, we must reject the contention.

facts.text: Lump sum rates for public carriers: below 5 tons Rs.420/annum general permit, etc.

anchor.surface_text: Public carriers  Goods Vehicles - Holding a general permit under the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939, to use all roads in Rajasthan- Load carrying capacity below 5 Tons Rs. 420 per annum. Load carrying capacity 5 Tons and above Rs. 540 per annum.
Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

issues.text: Whether the tax under the Act has been laid upon passengers and goods as authorised by Entry No. 56 of the State List or upon fares and freights which are different entities, effectively taxing income?

anchor.surface_text: the tax has not been laid upon passengers and goods as authorised by Entry No. 56 but upon fares and freights, which are different entities, and in support of the contention that there is a difference, reference is made to Entry No. 89 of the Union List,

issues.text: Whether the Act and the Rules are repugnant to Articles 301, 304, 19(1)(g) and 14 of the Constitution, including as a restriction on inter-State trade and discrimination with Railways?

anchor.surface_text: The Act and the Rules are further challenged on the grounds that they are repugnant to Arts. 301 and 304 as being a restriction upon inter-State trade, commerce and intercourse, to Art. 19 as involving an unreasonable restriction upon the business of the petitioners, and also to Art. 14

issues.text: Whether the Act confers unguided power on the State Government to fix the amount of lump sum payment in lieu of tax?

anchor.surface_text: The Act is further challenged on the ground that it concedes to the State Government the power to fix the amount of lump sum payment without guidance.

issues.text: Whether the rates and lump sum payments discriminate between routes involving roads of different surfaces violating Article 14?

anchor.surface_text: The rates and lump sum payment are challenged because they involve discrimination between routes involving roads of different surfaces.

issues.text: Whether Rules 8 and 8-A and the notification go beyond the Act by making lump sum payment compulsory (instead of optional) and requiring payment even when no passengers or goods are transported?

anchor.surface_text: Rules 8 and 8-A and the notification are challenged as, it is submitted, they go beyond the Act by making the lump sum payment compulsory, even though under the Act it is optional, and involve payment of tax even when no passengers or goods are transported.

issues.text: Whether the Act has extra-territorial operation by levying tax on intra-State journeys passing through another State?

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it is said that by making tax payable even though the route between two intra-State point passes outside the State, the Act has an extra-territorial operation which is ultra vires the legislature.

arguments.court_reasoning: Matter of policy, not from Act provisions

arguments.claim: Tax on p/g irrespective of distance leads to anomalies

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that if the tax were laid on passengers irrespective of the distance travelled by them, it would lead to anomalies if the amount charged be the same in every case.

arguments.claim: Incidence of tax on p/g per s.3 and Explanation

anchor.surface_text: We do not agree that the Act, in its pith, and substance, lays the tax upon income and not upon passengers and goods. Section 3, in terms, speaks of the charge of the tax in respect of all passengers carried and goods transported by motor vehicles,

arguments.claim: Similar view in precedents: Madras HC, Patna HC

anchor.surface_text: A similar argument was not accepted by the Madras High Court in Mathurai v. State of Madras, and the same view was expressed in Atma Ram Budhia v. State of Bihar.

arguments.claim: No inter-state impact; limited to state portions

anchor.surface_text: We are also of opinion that no inter-State trade, commerce or intercourse is affected. The tax is for purposes of State, and falls upon passengers and goods carried by motor vehicles within the State.

arguments.claim: Lump sum optional per permissive 'may accept' in s.4 provisos

anchor.surface_text: The two provisos to s. 4 are enabling, and thereby authorise the State Government to accept a lump sum payment in lieu of the tax actually chargeable. The word accept shows that the election to pay a lump sum is with the taxpayer,

arguments.claim: Rules subordinate to Act; read harmoniously, 'shall' directory/permissive

anchor.surface_text: The Act and the Rules must be read harmoniously, and reading them so, it is plain that the apparent mandatory language of the Rules and the notification still retains the permissive character of the section,

arguments.claim: 'Shall' not always mandatory; cites precedents (Lord Thurlow, Indian cases)

anchor.surface_text: The word shall is ordinarily mandatory, but it is sometimes not so interpreted if the context or the intention otherwise demands. ... There is abundance of authority to the contrary in cases where it has been held to be directory only.

arguments.claim: Lump sum rates reasonable (low figure per day)

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate-General pointed out that the lump sum rates work out at a very low figure, the minimum being less than Re. 1/- per day and the maximum, Rs. 1.50 nP. per day.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ct. It is companytended that the power to fix lump sums in lieu of tax has been companyferred upon G

arguments.court_reasoning: Rates reasonable but not sole basis; optional and averaged

arguments.claim: Lump sum based on averages from MV Act fares; good reasons (ease for operators/Govt)

anchor.surface_text: The fares and freights are fixed by competent authority under the Motor Vehicles Act, and that takes into account the average earnings, and the lump sum is fixed as an average of what tax would be realised if calculated on actual fares and freights.

arguments.claim: No discrimination road vs rail: constitutional classification, rail Union subject

anchor.surface_text: The comparison with Railways is not admissible, because tax on railway fares and freights is a Union subject, and is not available to the State Legislature. There is thus a clear classification made by the Constitution itself.

arguments.claim: Graded taxes justified by conveniences/costs of road types

anchor.surface_text: They will be heavy in case of roads requiring greater expenditure to construct and to maintain, than in case of roads not requiring such expenditure. All operators using the better kind of roads have to pay the heavier tax,

holdings.text: The Act, in its pith and substance, lays the tax upon passengers and goods and not upon income, and the charging section does not go outside Entry No. 56.

anchor.surface_text: We do not agree that the Act, in its pith, and substance, lays the tax upon income and not upon passengers and goods. Section 3, in terms, speaks of the charge of the tax in respect

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 3 charges tax in respect of passengers carried and goods transported; measure is fares/freights but incidence on p/g per Explanation; cites Madras and Patna HC precedents.

holdings.text: No inter-State trade, commerce or intercourse is affected by the tax, and the levy does not offend Arts. 301 and 304.

anchor.surface_text: We are also of opinion that no inter-State trade, commerce or intercourse is affected. The tax is for purposes of State, and falls upon passengers and goods carried by motor vehicles

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax limited to intra-state portions of journey; elaborate scheme in rules to proportion; exception in proviso separate.

holdings.text: Lump sum payment under Rules 8, 8-A and notification is optional, retaining permissive character of s.4 provisos; rules prescribe amounts harmoniously with Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Act and the Rules must be read harmoniously, and reading them so, it is plain that the apparent mandatory language of the Rules and the notification still retains the permissive

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Shall' not always mandatory (cites precedents); rules subordinate, fix rates only; election with taxpayer per 'may accept'.

holdings.text: Power to fix lump sum amounts is guided and constitutional; rates reasonable based on averages.

anchor.surface_text: The fares and freights are fixed by competent authority under the Motor Vehicles Act, and that takes into account the average earnings, and the lump sum is fixed as an average

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on MV Act fares/averages; optional; convenience for parties; low daily rates.

holdings.text: No discrimination under Art.14 between road transport and railways.

anchor.surface_text: The comparison with Railways is not admissible, because tax on railway fares and freights is a Union subject, and is not available to the State Legislature. There is thus a clear

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitutional classification: rail Union subject (List I); state limited to road.

holdings.text: No discrimination under Art.14 in graded tax rates for different road surfaces.

anchor.surface_text: Discrimination can only be found if it exists between persons who are comparable, and there is no comparison between persons using the better kind of roads and those who use roads

holdings.reasoning_summary: Taxes graded by construction/maintenance costs/conveniences provided; affects all users equally.

holdings.text: Proviso to s.3(3) not ultra vires for extra-territorial operation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Lack of evidence/affidavit on number/extent of routes; contention rejected on pleadings.

anchor.surface_text: Mathurai v. State of Madras  1 , and the same view was expressed in Atma Ram Budhia v. State of Bihar  2 . In our opinion, the charging section does I.L.R. 1954 Mad. 867.

precedents.cited_proposition: A tax measured by fares and freights is still a tax on passengers and goods carried by motor vehicles

precedents.case_name: Atma Ram Budhia v. State of Bihar
